sen.j: 紀成盛（きのなりもり、生没年不詳）は平安時代末期から鎌倉時代にかけて伯耆国西部（西伯耆）で勢力を誇っていた武士。
sen.e: KI no Narimori (dates of birth and death unknown) was an influential warrior in the western part of Hoki Province (Nishi Hoki) from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period.
KI no Narimori (dates of birth and death unknown) was an influential warrior in the western part of Hoki Province (Nishi Hoki) from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period.
KI no Narimori (year of birth and death unknown) was an influential warrior in the western part of Hoki Province (Nishi Hoki) from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 文献によっては「村尾海六(かいろく)」、「海六成盛」、「海陸業戍(かいろくなりもり)」、「村尾海六成盛」と記されている。
sen.e: His name was recorded in documents in various ways; 'Kairoku MURAO', 'Narimori KAIROKU', 'Kairoku NARIMORI' and 'Kairoku Nrimori MURAO.'
sen.cmt: 海六成盛, 村尾海六成盛の読み方が確認できませんでした。

sen.e: His name was recorded in documents in various ways; 'Kairoku MURAO,' 'Narimori KAIROKU,' 'Kairoku NARIMORI' and 'Kairoku Narimori MURAO.'

sen.j: 後年、息子と思われる人物に海六成国がいる。
sen.e: A person called Narikuni KAIROKU was considered his son.
sen.cmt: 「後年」は訳出しておりません。また、海六成国の読み方が確認できませんでした。
sen.e: A person called Narikuni KAIROKU is considered his son.
A person called Narikuni KAIROKU is considered his son.

sen.j: 紀成盛の一族、紀氏は元々中央の官人であったが伯耆守として赴任後、土着して在地領主となった。
sen.e: KI no Narimori was from the Ki clan, who were originally officials of the central government; after they came to Hoki Province as Hoki no kami, they settled there and became the local lords.
KI no Narimori was from the Ki clan, who were originally officials of the central government and after they came to Hoki Province as Hoki no kami, they settled there and became the local lords.
sen.cmt: セミコロン削除、and挿入しました。
sen.e: KI no Narimori was from the Ki clan, who were originally officials of the central government and after they came to Hoki Province as Hoki no kami, they settled there and became the local lords.

sen.j: 紀氏は会見郡東部を本拠地に勢力を拡大した。
sen.e: The Ki clan made Aimi County their home ground and became influential: according to "Daisenji engi (tales of the origin of Daisen-ji Temple)," the clan stepped in the conflict of Daisen-ji Temple in 1144; by that time the Ki clan had become so influential that they and the Ogamo clan of Higashi Hoki could divide Hoki Province into two.
sen.cmt: 大山寺の読み方は「Daisen-ji temple」としました。
sen.e: The Ki clan made the eastern part of Aimi County their home ground and became influential.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処、「東部」を挿入しました。
sen.e: The Ki clan made the eastern part of Aimi County their home ground and became influential.

sen.j: 『大山寺縁起』によれば康治3年（1144年）の大山寺内の抗争に関与し、この頃には東伯耆の小鴨氏と並んで伯耆国を二分するまでの勢力となっていた。
sen.e: According to "Daisenji engi (tales of the origin of Daisen-ji Temple)," the clan stepped in the conflict of Daisen-ji Temple in 1144 and by that time, the Ki clan had become so influential that they and the Ogamo clan of Higashi Hoki could divide Hoki Province into two.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処、セミコロン削除、and挿入しました。
sen.e: According to "Daisenji engi (tales of the origin of Daisen-ji Temple)," the clan stepped in the conflict of Daisen-ji Temple in 1144 and by that time, the Ki clan had become so influential that they and the Ogamo clan of Higashi Hoki could divide Hoki Province into two.

sen.j: 成盛が初めて登場するのは承安 (日本)3年（1173年）8月に奉納された大山寺鉄製厨子銘文である。
sen.e: Narimori first appeared in the inscription of the iron Zushi (a cupboard-like case with double doors in which an image of (the) Buddha, a sutra, or some other revered object is kept at a temple) of Daisen-ji Temple, dedicated in August, 1173.
sen.cmt: 大山寺の読み方は「Daisen-ji temple」としました。
sen.e: Narimori first appeared in the inscription of the iron Zushi (a cupboard-like case with double doors in which an image of Buddha, a sutra, or some other revered object is kept at a temple) of Daisen-ji Temple, dedicated in August, 1173.

Narimori first appeared in the inscription of the iron Zushi (a cupboard-like case with double doors in which an image of Buddha, a sutra, or some other revered object is kept at a temple) of Daisen-ji Temple, dedicated in August, 1173.

sen.j: ここには承安元年7月の火災によって大山寺の宝殿等が焼失、独力での再建が難しい寺に代わって成盛が再建したと記されている。
sen.e: According to the inscription, Narimori reestablished the holy shrine of the temple; it had been burnt to ashes in July, 1171 and it was difficult for the temple to reestablish it.
According to the inscription, Narimori reestablished the holy shrine of the temple which had been burnt to ashes in July, 1171 because it was difficult for the temple to reestablish it.
sen.cmt: セミコロン削除、which挿入、andを変更しました。
sen.e: According to the inscription, Narimori reestablished the holy shrine of the temple which had been burnt to ashes in July, 1171 because it was difficult for the temple to reestablish it.

tit.j: 源平合戦と伯耆の内乱
tit.e: The Genpei War and Domestic Conflicts in Hoki Province
The Genpei War and the Domestic Conflicts in Hoki Province
The Genpei War and the Domestic Conflicts in Hoki Province

sen.j: 前述したように平安末期の伯耆は紀氏と小鴨氏の二大勢力が存在しており、両氏の勢力拡大の折、度々衝突、合戦が行われていた。
sen.e: As mentioned before, there were the two powers, the Ki clan and the Ogamo clan, in Hoki Province at the end of the Heian period; both of them wanted to be more influential, which led to conflicts and battles.

As mentioned above, there were the two powers: the Ki clan and the Ogamo clan in Hoki Province in the end of the Heian period and both of them wanted to be more influential, which led to conflicts and battles.
sen.cmt: beforeを変更、コンマ挿入、セミコロン削除、コロン挿入しました。
sen.e: As mentioned above, there were the two powers: the Ki clan and the Ogamo clan in Hoki Province in the end of the Heian period and both of them wanted to be more influential, which led to conflicts and battles.

sen.j: 当時中央では源平合戦が行われており、その影響は地方にも拡大していた。
sen.e: The Genpei War, held in order to rule the country, affected rural areas.
The Genpei War, held around the capital at that time in order to rule the country, affected rural areas.
The Genpei War, held around the capital at that time in order to rule the country, affected rural areas.

sen.j: 伯耆国でも当初平氏側であった成盛ら西伯耆の武士が源氏方につくことにより平氏の小鴨、源氏の紀（村尾）という中央の対立を反映した構図が出来上がり、以前から続いていた抗争に拍車をかけることになった。
sen.e: The Nishi Hoki warriors, including Narimori, who had supported the Taira clan, changed their policy and supported the Genji clan while the Ogamo clan supported the Taira clan; that reflected the nation-wide confrontation and fueled the long-lasting conflicts between the Ki and Ogamo clans.

The Nishi Hoki warriors, including Narimori, who had first supported the Taira clan but changed their policy to support the Minamoto clan while the Ogamo clan supported the Taira clan; that reflected the nation-wide confrontation and fueled the long-lasting conflicts between the Ki (Murao) and Ogamo clans.
sen.cmt: Muraoを挿入、andの削除、Genji clanを変更しました。
sen.e: The Nishi Hoki warriors, including Narimori, who had first supported the Taira clan but changed their policy to support the Minamoto clan while the Ogamo clan supported the Taira clan; that reflected the nation-wide confrontation and fueled the long-lasting conflicts between the Ki (Murao) and Ogamo clans.

sen.j: 「吉記」によると寿永元年（1182年）8月、成盛は小鴨基保との間で隣国の武士をも巻き込む大規模な合戦を行い勝利、2年後の寿永3年には「院の御子」を称する者を担ぎ上げて一時は伯耆の半分、美作国の一部を支配下に入れた。（「玉葉」寿永3年2月2日の条）
sen.e: According to 'Kikki (a diary of Tunefusa YOSHIDA),' Narimori and Motoyasu OGAMO had a large-scale battle, inbolving warriors in neighboring provinces in August, 1182, and the Ki clan defeated the Ogamo clan; in 1184, Narimori welcomed a would-be 'IN no Miko (a retired emperor's child)' as if he were a real one; Narimori ruled half of Hoki Province and some parts of Mimasaka Province for a while.
sen.cmt: 小鴨基保の読みが確認できておりません。
sen.e: According to 'Kikki (a diary of Tunefusa YOSHIDA),' Narimori defeated Motoyasu OGAMO in a large-scale battle inｖolving warriors in neighboring provinces in August, 1182, and in 1184, Narimori set up self-professed 'IN no Miko (a retired emperor's child)' as their head and ruled the half of Hoki Province and some parts of Mimasaka Province for a while (the article of February 2, 1184 of "Gyokuyo [Diary of Kanezane KUJO]").
sen.cmt: コンマ削除、スペルミス訂正、「自称」を変更、「担ぎあげる」を変更、「（「玉葉」寿永3年2月2日の条）」の移動、括弧挿入、article ofを挿入しました。
sen.e: According to 'Kikki (a diary of Tunefusa YOSHIDA),' Narimori defeated Motoyasu OGAMO in a large-scale battle inｖolving warriors in neighboring provinces in August, 1182, and in 1184, Narimori set up self-professed 'IN no Miko (a retired emperor's child)' as their head and ruled the half of Hoki Province and some parts of Mimasaka Province for a while (the article of February 2, 1184 of "Gyokuyo [Diary of Kanezane KUJO]").

sen.j: 「小鴨家系図」によれば当時、平宗盛の求めに応じて出兵中であった小鴨基保は急遽帰国して成盛の軍と戦った。
sen.e: (Gyokuyo (Diary of Kanezane KUJO), on February 2, 1184) According to 'the genealogy of the Ogamo clan,' Motoyasu OGAMO had left his territory, leading his army, by Munemori TAIRA's request; on hearing the news, Motoyasu quickly came back to Hoki Province and fought against the Narimori's army.

According to 'the genealogy of the Ogamo clan,' Motoyasu OGAMO had left his territory leading his army by Munemori TAIRA's request, and on hearing the news, Motoyasu quickly came back to Hoki Province to fight against the Narimori's army.
sen.cmt: コンマの多用を訂正しました。
sen.e: According to 'the genealogy of the Ogamo clan,' Motoyasu OGAMO had left his territory leading his army by Munemori TAIRA's request, and on hearing the news, Motoyasu quickly came back to Hoki Province to fight against the Narimori's army.

sen.j: 伯耆国の内乱の終結後、成盛に関する文献は途絶える。
sen.e: Nothing was recorded about Narimori after the conflicts in Hoki Province ended.
Nothing was recorded about Narimori after the conflicts in Hoki Province ended.
Nothing was recorded about Narimori after the conflicts in Hoki Province ended.

sen.j: おそらく、中央での平氏滅亡に反して源氏方の成盛は平氏方の基保との戦いに敗れ滅亡したものと考えられる。
sen.e: It is thought that Narimori, a Genji-clan supporter, was defeated and killed by Motoyasu, a Taira-clan supporter, although the Genji-clan defeated the Taira-clan throughout Japan.
It is thought that Narimori supporting the Minamoto clan was defeated and killed by Motoyasu supporting the Taira clan, although the Minamoto clan defeated the Taira clan in the captal.

sen.j: 後の南北朝時代 (日本)から登場する進氏は紀氏の後裔と称し、成盛をその祖としている。
sen.e: The Shin clan, who appeared later in Japanese histroy, in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), called themselves the descendants of the Ki clan and called Narimori their ancestor.
